This enigmatical poem is an in- vective directed against some enemy, whose name is with- held, but who appears to have made an effort to ruin Ovid's reputation at Rome after he was banished. It calls down upon the head of the offender all the curses known to the language of mythology as well as of passion. Ovid appears to have borrowed both the idea and the title of the poem from the Greek poet Callimachus.
